hobby.message: Political literature or political theater tonight?
Still folding origami to stay grounded?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Not really. I—took the side route tonight.
Can’t risk too much attention lately, with all the patrols out.
I fold origami sometimes, just paper—nothing special.
Everyone’s watching what we use paper for now.
Side streets take longer, but it seemed safer.
Had to wait outside, patrols stopped someone up the block.
I spend time folding origami to unwind—in private mostly.
People swapping paper for those memory trades makes it harder now.
I just keep my models out of sight.
Walked the long way, city feels tense since those Memory Markets spread.
Origami is my thing—folding, modular stars, cranes, even tessellations.
Feels odd, keeping blank paper hidden like it’s contraband.
Some of my neighbors trade scraps for the markets. Makes me careful what I use.
I had to move my paper stash last week.
That’s how it goes, I guess.
Yeah, longer than usual—avoiding scans and checkpoints.
Honestly, these days I fold origami to stay calm. Like real models, not just cranes.
Used to sit by the window, work on big modular pieces, stacks of paper everywhere.
After the Council started cracking down, I keep supplies hidden—people get suspicious if you have too much.
Some neighbors asked me for paper, for those Memory Market things.
Feels strange being nervous about folding a star.
I even hid finished models for the first time.
Walk took twice as long, had to circle around three patrols on the way.
I unwind with origami—complex models, precise, sometimes dozens of pieces per star.
Before all this, nobody cared if you hoarded blank forms, now it’s risky.
Last week, someone knocked just to ask for scraps, wanted to share them at a Memory Market.
Strange how paper became precious overnight, not for info but for memory.
It’s personal—folding keeps my anxiety at bay. Lately, I feel watched every step.
Council agents flagged someone in my building just for ‘excess craft materials.’
Part of me worries even a folded paper swan might count as evidence now.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Folded a couple cranes last week.
Not much time lately. Too many building checks.
Someone asked for paper yesterday. Seemed odd.
Probably nothing, just people being people.
Feels like even hobbies get noticed now.
Folded some basic stars at home. Nothing complicated.
Memory Markets made paper hard to come by.
Neighbors trade scraps for those gatherings. Strange times.
I’ve cut back, just in case.
A Directorate agent stopped by—made me rethink leaving anything out.
Not sure what counts as safe anymore.
Yeah, a few modular stars and tessellations. Helps me unwind after work.
Paper’s oddly valuable now, thanks to those Memory Markets.
People using origami to pass stories, not just to pass time.
Had a neighbor show up needing blank pages for the markets.
Sometimes I worry folding at home might draw the wrong attention.
It’s odd—what felt harmless suddenly feels risky.
Guess that’s Stenograd, lately.
Definitely folded something new—split-rhombus tessellations. Challenging with scrap paper, though.
Memory Markets changed everything. People haunt stairwells trading folded notes.
I had to hide my own origami models last week.
A neighbor I barely knew asked for paper for the first time ever.
They’re using receipts, ration slips—even lab request forms.
It’s like even creativity is suspicious now. Makes me nervous, honestly.
Sometimes folding helps me forget. Sometimes it just reminds me how strange things are.
Feels like the BCI can trace even a paper swan.
Yeah—I’ve been working on advanced sonobe cubes, but hiding them now.
Since the Memory Markets started, blank paper’s a currency. Didn’t expect that.
A neighbor knocked, desperate for anything to write on. I gave away old Directorate forms.
Used to leave origami everywhere—gifts, stress relief. Now I stash everything out of sight.
Feels like paper’s being watched. Even folding gets second-guessed.
I feel more exposed crafting than running reports.
Council’s surveillance meant to catch conspiracies, but it’s targeting things like this instead.
Origami was my quiet rebellion, now it’s almost evidence against me.
Honestly, sometimes I miss when systems worried about bigger threats than a folded crane.
